lesson.name: Creating an Express Server From Scratch
lesson.summary:
In this lesson, youâ€™ll cover the basics of setting up an express server from scratch.

Express is a great framework and it makes setting up your server a breeze.

solution.solution: const express = require('express'); const app = express(); const PORT = 3000; app.listen(PORT, () => { console.log(`Server running at http://localhost:${PORT}`); });

tasks.name: install express
tasks.explanation: First things first, we need to install express and import it as a dependency.

tasks.name: import express

tasks.name: initialize a new instance of express
tasks.explanation: Nice work! Now we need to declare a new constant called app and initialise it to an instance of express, in order to access some of its properties and methods later in the build.

tasks.name: choose a port
tasks.explanation: Great! Now itâ€™s time to decide what port youâ€™d like your server to run on - for this exercise we recommend you use port 3000. Create a new constant called PORT and set it equal to your chosen port.

tasks.name: listen to your port
tasks.explanation:
Almost there! Finally we need our app to listen to our port to receive data. To do this, you can use the .listen method:

app.listen(YOUR-PORT, () => {})

Insert your port variable and add a fun console.log

Now you have a functioning server, you can run your code in the terminal.

hints.title: Install Express
hints.content: To install express we recommend using npm - the command is â€˜npm install expressâ€™ - write this in your terminal and see what happens

hints.title: Import Express
hints.content:
Type this in your code editor:

const express = require('express');

hints.title: Initialize a New Instance of Express
hints.content:
Create a constant named 'app', then save an invocation of your express function to 'app'.

Like this: 'const app = express();'

hints.title: Choose a Port
hints.content: Ports can be a complicated business, so in terms of this tutorial itâ€™s best to think of them as a place for your server to look for data

hints.title: Listen to Your Port
hints.content:
Here we need to add where we want our server to listen out - our chosen port.

In the callback function (squiggly brackets) add a console log. Make it fun, this is what youâ€™ll see when your server is up and running. We love to see emojis ðŸš€

To finally run your code, type 'node index.js' in your terminal and hit RUN.

hints.title: Add a Link to Localhost
hints.content:
Notice how we use a template literal (the backticks) and the ${}? This allows us to insert our javascript variables into the string. What does this mean? Well, here it means javascript will read it as:

`Server running at http://localhost:3000 ðŸš€`

Using template literals makes your code more modular and saves you from having to change your console log if you decide to listen on a different port
